awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide renewed funding of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site. The REU program will be offered annually to fifteen qualified applicants in three locations: Socorro, NM; Green Bank, WV; and Charlottesville, VA. These sites are the headquarters for the operations of the Very Large Array (VLA) and Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA), Green Bank Telescope (GBT), and Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), respectively. Students will perform cutting-edge research in several areas, including all fields of astronomy (cosmology, extragalactic, galactic, stellar, solar system, astrochemistry, pulsars, etc.), as well as astronomical engineering and computing. In addition to their assigned research project, all students participate in a hands-on observing experience using the NRAO GBT, VLA, and/or VLBA. 

The award will enable a pipeline of skilled scientists and engineers to be developed in the field of radio astronomy, which is critical for the infrastructure of NSF-funded facilities. The program has also demonstrated its effectiveness in retaining students in STEM fields: indeed, over 300 past participants remain in the field of astronomy. Finally, participants also receive instruction and experience with communicating their scientific research through oral and written presentation of their research project results, including the opportunity to present their research at a professional meeting following their appointment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Radio Astonomy Observatory (NRAO) and Green Bank Observatory (GBO) offer undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in summer research through the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. This program allows students to immerse themselves in astronomical research using cutting-edge facilities, acquire hands-on experience in the field of radio astronomy, and collaborate closely with Observatory scientists and engineers.  Summer research is supported at three sites: NRAO in Socorro, NM; NRAO in Charlottesville, VA; and GBO in Green Bank, WV.  The REU program is the cornerstone to a rich and diverse NRAO/GBO summer cohort that includes both undergraduate and graduate students working together and collaborating on research with scientists and engineers at all levels, from postdocs to senior advisors.  Over the three year period 2019-2021, the program supported 49 REU students and the broader NRAO/GBO summer programs hosted 115 summer students, overall.  In 2019, students conducted their research in person at the observatory sites, and during the pandemic years 2020-2021 they worked on their projects remotely.

Each student participates in a research project mentored by an NRAO/GBO scientist or engineer.  Our mentors provide projects that emphasize the student's educational experience.  Students see the research process through all its stages, including data acquisition, reduction, analysis, and presentation. Research projects cover a wide range of astrophysical topics, from studies of the Solar System to the farthest reaches of the universe. In addition to their assigned research projects, students participate in a week-long, undergraduate-focused workshop at the beginning of the summer where they hear lectures on radio astronomy and engineering, participate in hands-on observing projects, and engage in career-development panel discussions and activities.  In 2019 the workshop was held in Green Bank, where the students got tours of the site and its telescopes and worked in teams with hands-on observing projects.  During the pandemic years the workshop was conducted remotely, including remote operation of telescopes for their team projects.  Over the course of the summer, students also participate in seminars to help them explore career opportunties in STEM fields and to help those interested prepare for graduate school.  They also engage in public outreach, for example by giving tours of the Very Large Array (VLA).  At the conclusion of the summer, students submit research reports and finally give talks on their research projects to Observatory staff in a Summer Student Symposium.

The NRAO/GBO summer program fosters a diverse student base, and we include programs, opportunities, and training specifically to foster broadening  participation from groups under-represented in STEM fields, including women and minorities.
